isis.stitle: International® MaxxForce™ 7 Engine Service Manual - Crankcase, Crankshaft, and Camshaft - Cleaning, Inspection, and Testing - Crankcase Assembly

note.para: Thoroughly clean and inspect upper and lower crankcase assemblies before and after reconditioning.

step1.para: Clean upper and lower crankcase assemblies in a chemical bath or hot tank. This removes all carbonized material and mineral deposits in coolant passages.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: If a hot tank is not available, do the following steps:

step2.para: Use non-metallic stiff bristle brushes and scrapers to clean gasket material from machined surfaces of upper crankcase assembly.
Clean cylinder bore with soap, water, and a stiff nylon brush.
Clean upper and lower crankcase assemblies in solvent.

step1.para: Remove main oil gallery cup plugs (in rear of upper crankcase assembly) using a punch and hammer near edge of plug and striking with hammer.
Remove plugs from upper crankcase assembly and discard.
Clean main oil galleries with oil gallery cleaning brush ZTSE4511 .

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, install gasket and cover within 5 minutes of Liquid Gasket (RTV) application to inhibit the formation of a skin and ensure a leak proof joint.

note.para:
Use Liquid Gasket (RTV)
before installing main oil gallery cup plugs.

step1.para:
Coat edges of new oil gallery cup plugs with Liquid Gasket (RTV) . Use oil gallery plug driver ZTSE4512
and install new oil gallery cup plugs. The oil gallery plug driver installs oil gallery cup plugs to correct depth. They should be flush with upper crankcase assembly surface to approximately 1.50 mm (0.060 in) below surface.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, clean and dry threads in the upper crankcase assembly bolt holes with filtered compressed air. Dirt or oil in holes may cause binding and incorrect torque readings.

step1.para: Clean cylinder head bolt holes with head bolt bottoming tap ZTSE4508 .

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: Blow out chips with filtered compressed air.
After cleaning, inspect upper crankcase assembly for cracks, scoring, roughness or wear at cylinder bores.

figure.caption: Flatness check for top surface of upper crankcase assembly

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, do not resurface the crankcase if surface defects exceed specifications.

step1.para:
Use a straightedge
to check top surface of upper crankcase assembly (firing deck) for flatness. Insert a feeler gauge
between straightedge and upper crankcase assembly head surface.

step2.para: Measure entire deck surface. If gap exceeds specifications , replace upper crankcase assembly.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, if cylinder bores are deeply scored, out-of-round or exceed specifications, bore out cylinders to oversize specification.

note.para:
If cylinder walls have minor surface damage, but are otherwise within out-of-round specifications, it may be possible to remove damage by deglazing
.

step1.para:
Use a cylinder bore gauge
to check cylinder bore out-of-round conditions.

step2.para: Measure diameter of each cylinder bore at top of piston ring travel. Be sure to measure at a right angle to center line of crankshaft assembly (dimension A).
Measure each bore so gauge reading coincides with center line of crankshaft assembly (dimension B).
The difference between dimension A and dimension B is out-of-round condition at top of cylinder bore.

step1.para: Repeat procedure at bottom of ring travel to check for out-of-round condition.

note.para:
If cylinder bore is suitable for use without reconditioning, deglaze cylinder bore before assembling. See Cylinder Deglazing
for further details.

step1.para: If cylinder bore is within specifications , standard size pistons and rings may be used.

note.para: Remove piston cooling tubes before deglazing cylinder bores.

step1.para:
Use deglazing hone (four inch) ZTSE4349
to deglaze cylinder bore. This brush quickly deglazes cylinder walls and produces a crosshatch pattern on cylinder wall surface in a single operation. The brush contours itself to cylinder wall and conditions wall surface without altering cylinder bore.
Spray cylinder and deglazing hone with penetrating fluid or equivalent.

note.para: For a successful procedure 100 to 120 rpm is required.

step1.para: Attach deglazing hone to a variable speed electric or air powered drill.

note.para: Do not allow deglazing hone to spin in one place. Deglazing hone must be moved in a constant up and down motion to maintain crosshatch pattern.

step1.para: Deglaze cylinder wall for about 15 seconds. Stroke bore up and down at a rate of one complete up and down stroke per second.
Withdraw deglazing hone from cylinder bore while rotating. Wipe portion of cylinder wall and inspect crosshatch pattern.

note.para: The crosshatch pattern left by the abrasive tool should be approximately 45°. If pattern is flatter than required, increase up and down stroke speed or slow down drill rotation as required.

step1.para: Continue deglazing cylinder bore for 10 to 15 seconds or 20 to 25 strokes.
Wipe cylinder bore clean and inspect bore for correct 45° crosshatch pattern.
After deglazing, thoroughly clean cylinder bores with soft bristle brush, soap and water.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: Dry with filtered compressed air.
Lubricate bores with clean engine oil
